results.name: A triangle formed like Pascal's triangle, but with 3^n on the borders instead of 1.
comment: All rows except the zeroth are divisible by 3. Is there a closed-form formula for these numbers, like for binomial coefficients?

Let b=3 and T(n,k) = A(n-k,k) be the associated reading of the symmetric array A by antidiagonals, then A(n,k) = sum_{r=1..n} b^r*A178300(n-r,k) + sum_{c=1..k} b^c*A178300(k-c,n). Similarly with b=4 and b=5 for A227074 and A227076. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 10 2013
link: T. D. Noe, Rows n = 0..50 of triangle, flattened
mathematica: t = {}; Do[r = {}; Do[If[k == 0 || k == n, m = 3^n, m = t[[n, k]] + t[[n, k + 1]]]; r = AppendTo[r, m], {k, 0, n}]; AppendTo[t, r], {n, 0, 10}]; t = Flatten[t]

Cf. A051601 (n on the borders), A137688 (2^n on borders).
